title: The Wall Street Journal: Russia to expand U.S. blacklist in retaliation for Trump sanctions
text:
Published: Mar 16, 2018 6:48 a.m. ET Share 
U.S. sanctioned 19 individuals and 5 entities, in what analysts say is a largely symbolic strike against the Kremlin AFP/Getty Images President Donald Trump and Russia's President Vladimir Putin shake hands during a meeting on the sidelines of the G20 Summit in July. 
By Thomas Grove 
MOSCOW—Russia plans to expand its blacklist of Americans in retribution for new U.S. sanctions and could take additional steps to escalate a growing standoff between Russia and the West, a top Russian diplomat said Friday. 
President Donald Trump’s administration introduced its first round of sanctions against Russia this week for Moscow’s meddling in the 2016 presidential election and hacking into critical U.S. infrastructure like power grids. Washington has also backed growing European criticism of the Kremlin for its alleged role in the poisoning of a former Russian spy in the U.K. ‘From the very beginning we have supported parity regarding the number of individuals included in the sanctions list. Other steps are possible on our part, which we will calibrate, according to our own interests.’ Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov 
The U.S. measures sanction 19 individuals and five entities, some of whom have already been hit by previous rounds, in what analysts agree is largely a symbolic strike against the Kremlin. 
Russian President Vladimir Putin, who is expected to win a presidential election on Sunday, has played the increasing tensions with the West to his advantage at home, presenting himself as a leader who can stand up to Europe and the U.S., who want to see Moscow brought to its knees. 
Further measures from Moscow, although also likely more symbolic than practical, would represent the first escalation of a diplomatic tit-for-tat since last July. Then Moscow demanded Washington cut 755 diplomats and embassy staff in Russia in response to the administration of former President Barack Obama’s expulsion of 35 Russian diplomats from the U.S.
